channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russian Pledge to Ease Attack Is Greeted Skeptically by West
item.description: As Russian and Ukrainian negotiators met face to face for the first time in weeks, Russia said a meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelensky could occur once a draft peace agreement was ready.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers advanced through the streets of Irpin, a suburb of Kyiv, as they conducted a clearing operation on Tuesday. Russian troops had recently held the area.

item.title: Palestinian Gunman Kills 5 in Israel’s Fifth Attack in Recent Days
item.description: The attack in a Tel Aviv suburb brought the number of people killed in the past two weeks to 11, making it one of the deadliest periods in Israel in several years.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:description: Israeli security and medical personnel at the scene of an attack in Bnei Brak, near Tel Aviv, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Desperate for Cash, Afghans Toil in Mines That Are Deadlier Than Ever
item.description: Faced with life-threatening hunger, thousands labor in the coal mines of Baghlan. But safety measures that the former government once provided are gone.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

item.title: Mariupol Residents Describe How Russian Forces Deprived Them of Food and Water
item.description: Residents of Mariupol, Ukraine described how Russian forces use hunger as a weapon of war in a monthlong siege of the southern port. “No roof, no food and no water,” survivors texted relatives who escaped.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ben Hubbard and Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia Beley, center, with her daughter and friends from Mariupol at a shelter in Lviv, western Ukraine.

item.title: A Vow to Ease Bombing Is Too Late for Many in Ukraine City Near Kyiv
item.description: Russia’s offer, if honored, comes too late for the thousands who have already fled Chernihiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna Shepetova escaped from Chernihiv with her three children and her mother on one of the last minibuses out of the city last week, as Russian forces were closing in.

item.title: Women Drive Germany’s Foreign Policy Shift Amid Ukraine War
item.description: Angela Merkel is no longer chancellor. But as war rages in Ukraine, a mere 10-hour drive from Berlin, female ministers oversee national security.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Christine Lambrecht, the German defense minister, visiting the Ninth Panzerlehr Brigade of the armed forces, in Münster, Germany, in February.

item.title: Prince Andrew, Banished From Royal Duties, Escorts Queen to Memorial
item.description: The prince’s conspicuous public appearance at the service for his father, Prince Philip, who died last year, sent an unmistakable message of support by a 95-year-old mother for her disgraced son.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s Queen Elizabeth, accompanied by Prince Andrew, Duke of York, attending a service of thanksgiving for late Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, at Westminster Abbey in London, Britain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Shanghai’s Lockdown Tests Covid-Zero Policy, and People’s Limits
item.description: A staggered lockdown on China’s commercial capital of 26 million people has sent beleaguered residents scrambling and raised fears of broader damage to the economy.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: A worker in protective gear received food from a delivery man while guarding the entrance to a neighborhood under lockdown in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Summit Mixes Historic Symbolism With Sharp Disputes
item.description: The meeting of diplomats from Israel, the U.S. and four Arab countries was momentous just for taking place. But in private, they tried to hash out differences over Iran and the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A group photo after the talks: Abdullatif bin Rashid al-Zayani of Bahrain, Sameh Shoukry of Egypt, Yair Lapid of Israel, Antony J. Blinken of the United States, Nasser Bourita of Morocco and Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed al-Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Solomon Islands’ Leader Calls Concern Over China Security Deal ‘Insulting’
item.description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare criticized Australia and New Zealand as assuming that the island nation could not act in its own best interests.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, left, of the Solomon Islands met with the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: London Police Issue Fines for Downing Street Lockdown Parties
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was not among those penalized, his office said, but the police decision puts a perilous political scandal back in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving Downing Street in London last week. He has steadfastly denied that he violated any lockdown rules.

item.title: Hundreds Arrested in El Salvador, Raising Fears of a Civil Liberties Crackdown
item.description: The Salvadoran government’s response to the weekend’s gang violence that left dozens dead is stoking fears that the emergency measures will allow President Nayib Bukele to further consolidate power.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: In this handout photo made available by the government of El Salvador, gang members waited outside their cells during a search at the Ciudad Barrios jail on Sunday.

item.title: President Macron’s Unending Russia Diplomacy
item.description: The French leader’s outreach to his counterparts in Russia and Ukraine is stubborn. Whether it is also effective remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking at a meeting of NATO and G7 leaders in Brussels last Thursday.

item.title: Sanctioned Oligarch’s Presence Adds Intrigue to Ukraine-Russia Talks
item.description: Roman Abramovich, sanctioned owner of the Chelsea Football Club, mysteriously showed up at the talks between Ukraine and Russia in Istanbul, and is said to be playing an unofficial role.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch who owns the Chelsea Football Club, center-rear, during peace talks in Istanbul, in an image from video provided by the Turkish president’s office, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukrainian Military Fends Off Russia and Retakes Suburb of Kyiv
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers have essentially retaken, for now, the town of Irpin, the scene of fierce fighting in recent weeks. Its success shows the steep challenges Russia faces in trying to capture Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters of the Odin Unit, including some foreign fighters from the United States and Britain, waiting to advance during a clearing-out operation of remaining Russian forces on Tuesday in Irpin, Ukraine.

item.title: Peace Talks May Be Little More Than Russian Tactics, Analysts Say
item.description: As signs of progress emerged during the peace talks, some saw them as Russia buying time to regroup its military forces before another offensive push in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Cetin Muhurdar/Turkish Presidential Press Service, via AFP -- Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey during the Ukrainian-Russian talks in Istanbul on Tuesday.

item.title: The Fighters Who Took Over a Retail Store to Defend Kyiv
item.description: As Russia pledges to scale back operations in Kyiv, soldiers from the 112th Brigade of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense are still preparing for the worst. Our cameras went inside their makeshift base.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Benjamin Foley for The New York Times

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Signal Progress, but No End to War Is in Sight
item.description: Russia said it would “drastically” reduce military activity around Kyiv, while Ukraine said it would be willing to accept neutrality and discuss territorial claims to resolve the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighters of the Ukrainian Odin Unit, including foreign volunteers, among them Americans and Britons, in Irpin, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: BA.2 Accounts for Over Half of New U.S. Cases, C.D.C. Estimates
item.description: Scientists have been keeping an eye on BA.2, one of three distinct genetically distinct varieties of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a coronavirus test at a drive-through testing site in Hagerstown, Md., last month.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Enter a New Phase in Istanbul
item.description: “All the world is expecting good news from you,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in greeting the Russian and Ukrainian delegations.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Murat Cetin Muhurdar/Turkish Presidential Press Service, via AFP – Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey speaking on Tuesday before talks between Ukrainian and Russian negotiators in Istanbul, in a photo provided by the Turkish presidential press service.

item.title: Britain Seizez Russian Superyacht
item.description: The British authorities have joined those nations putting pressure on Vladimir Putin by targeting the assets of his wealthy supporters.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Russian-owned superyacht Phi seized by Britain on Tuesday.

item.title: Accounts of Russian Rapes Are Growing, Ukraine Officials Say
item.description: A Ukrainian woman’s account of being repeatedly raped was published in The Times of London, and a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said there were “many more” such assaults.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Marina Goldovskaya, 80, Dies; Filmmaker Documented Russian Life
item.description: In about 30 documentaries she looked at the people and history of her homeland, some of it brutally dark.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Ramsey

item.title: Gunmen Attack Train Near Nigerian Capital, Killing Some Riders
item.description: The attackers used explosives to blow up the rail track before opening fire on the train in the latest in a series of train assaults.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Could the U.S. do More for Ukraine?
item.description: President Biden says that Ukraine has the full support of the U.S. Volodymyr Zelensky disagrees.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleg, 61, in Kyiv, after being shot in the leg by Russian forces.

item.title: Farhana Yamin’s Journey From Climate Summits to Street Protests
item.description: After a high-profile career as an international lawyer and negotiator, Farhana Yamin decided “we cannot rely on lawyers and diplomats alone.”
item.dc:creator: Mélissa Godin
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Farhana Yamin, one of the architects of the Paris climate agreement, at a protest in London in 2019.

item.title: A Brutal Russian Playbook Reapplied in Ukraine
item.description: The besieging of cities, the deliberate targeting of civilians — they are the tactics Russia used before, in Grozny. I saw it firsthand.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine reports some battle successes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Damaged Russian tank in the town of Trostyanets, east of capital Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus deaths in the U.S. fall to their lowest point since the summer.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: People visiting the cherry blossoms in Washington on Friday. New Covid-19 cases are rising in the nation’s capital.

item.title: Biden Says of Condemning Putin: ‘I Make No Apologies’
item.description: President Biden said his words, delivered in a speech over the weekend in Warsaw, were not a call for regime change in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden announcing his budget for Fiscal Year 2023, which reduces deficits by more than $1 trillion over the next decade, in the White House on Monday.

item.title: Marco Rubio Leads G.O.P. Push for a More Combative Stance on China
item.description: It’s time for Americans to buckle down for a long struggle with Beijing, the Florida senator will argue in a speech.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
item.media:description: Republicans like Senator Marco Rubio have made opposition to China and its leader, Xi Jinping, central to their foreign policy.

item.title: Ukraine Claims Some Battle Successes as Russia Focuses on Another Front
item.description: With the fighting raging and sputtering attempts at diplomacy continuing, diplomacy between the two sides was continuing, with talks planned in Istanbul on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers rest in Kyiv, Ukraine, after their day fighting out on the front lines north of the capital on Monday.

item.title: Honduran Supreme Court Ratifies U.S. Extradition Request of Ex-President
item.description: The former leader of Honduras is accused of colluding with drug cartels to ship tons of cocaine to the United States in return for financial support for his political party.
item.dc:creator: Joan Suazo and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, the former president of Honduras, speaking in Tegucigalpa last August.

item.title: Would Putin Strike NATO Supply Lines to Ukraine? History Suggests No.
item.description: From the Soviets in Afghanistan to the U.S. in Korea, Moscow and Washington have often chosen not to attack the countries aiding their enemies.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A shipment of Javelin antitank missiles arrived in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month. Some analysts say a vigorous NATO supply campaign could lead to a Russian military failure.

item.title: ‘Drive My Car’ Oscar Is a Slow-Burn Return for Japan’s Cinema
item.description: But some of the same qualities that made the film popular overseas have led to a cooler reception domestically.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Ryusuke Hamaguchi, right, the director of “Drive My Car,” celebrating on Sunday after the film won an Academy Award for best international feature.

item.title: Pope Francis Meets With Canadian Indigenous Leaders Seeking Apology
item.description: For the first time, Francis received Indigenous survivors of abusive boarding schools in Canada who were seeking the pontiff’s apology over the church’s role in running the schools.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Métis National Council president Cassidy Caron, second from left, walking alongside Angie Crerar, 85, a survivor of the Métis Residential School, and other delegates from Canada’s First Nations after a meeting with Pope Francis on Monday.

item.title: India General Strike Protests Narendra Modi’s Economic Policies
item.description: The two-day strike, involving both public and private sector workers, was called to protest the Modi government’s economic policies, including a privatization plan.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Commuters on a train that was blocked by protesters at a railway station in Kolkata on Monday.

item.title: Reducing Covid’s Toll
item.description: Many experts expect Covid caseloads to rise soon. Here are four steps to protect people.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing boosters in Washington last month.

item.title: Befriending Trees to Lower a City’s Temperature
item.description: A program in Melbourne, Australia, that tracks every public tree — and even gives each an email address — is seen as a way to manage climate change.
item.dc:creator: Peter Wilson
item.media:credit: Alana Holmberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: As part of its efforts to protect and enhance Melbourne’s tree cover, some 3,000 trees are planted in the city each year. This juvenile Cinnamomum camphor laurel tree was planted on Exhibition Street in Melbourne’s central business district in 2021.

item.title: Does Social Media Make Teens Unhappy? It May Depend on Their Age.
item.description: A large study in Britain found two specific windows of adolescence when some teenagers are most sensitive to social media.
item.dc:creator: Virginia Hughes
item.media:credit: In Pictures Ltd./Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Responses from people of all ages in Britain found two distinct periods of adolescence when heavy use of social media spurred gloomy feelings: first around puberty and again around age 19.

item.title: Geofencing Improves Safety in Sweden
item.description: Sweden has long been at the forefront of road innovation and is again leading the way with trials of a technology known as geofencing.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Mohn

item.title: When Nokia Pulled Out of Russia, a Vast Surveillance System Remained
item.description: The Finnish company played a key role in enabling Russia’s cyberspying, documents show, raising questions of corporate responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
item.media:description: The Moscow headquarters of the F.S.B. intelligence service, which uses a surveillance network that Nokia helped run smoothly.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s new tactics in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Charred cars and a heavily damaged apartment building on Sunday in Mariupol, Ukraine, which was in increasingly dire straits.

item.title: El Salvador Declares State of Emergency After Gang Killings
item.description: Gangs went on a killing spree, gunning down anyone on the street. At least 62 were killed on Saturday, the deadliest day on record since the country’s civil war ended 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar
item.media:description: Soldiers at a checkpoint in San Salvador, the capital of El Salvador, on Sunday.

item.title: Zelensky Gives Interview to Russian Journalists. Moscow Orders It Quashed.
item.description: The remarkable interview was still published by journalists outside of Russia, an episode that laid bare the extraordinary, and partly successful, efforts at censorship by Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke with some prominent members of the Russian media via video on Sunday.

item.title: Concerns rise as a U.S. reimbursement fund for uninsured Covid patients stops taking claims.
item.description: Some U.S. health care providers are informing uninsured people they can no longer be tested for the virus free of charge and will have to pay for the service.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:description: Loading a tray of test tubes into a P.C.R. analysis machine at a Quest Diagnostics lab in Indianapolis last month.

item.title: After Biden’s Fiery Speech, Nine Unscripted Words Reverberate
item.description: Administration officials were forced to walk back the ad-lib that Russian President Vladimir V. Putin “cannot remain in power,” which captured the attention of foreign policy experts, lawmakers and allies.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the Royal Castle in Warsaw on Saturday. His speech was intended to highlight U.S. support for its European allies, but the president veered off-script.

item.title: As Ukraine War Moves Into 2nd Month, Fears Grow of Mariupol’s Fall to Russia
item.description: Ukraine’s top military intelligence officer suggested that Russia was changing its military focus to the south and east and might be trying to divide the country.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Charred cars and a heavily damaged apartment building on Sunday in Mariupol, Ukraine, which was in increasingly dire straits.

item.title: In Lviv, New Russian Strikes Pierce the Sense of Security in West
item.description: Residents in the western city of Lviv once ignored the air raid sirens. But Russian rocket attacks over the weekend have brought the war closer to their doorstep.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters at a fuel storage facility that was struck by a Russian missile in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Arab Gunmen Kill 2 in Hadera, on Eve of Historic Summit
item.description: The unusually brazen attack in Hadera, a city on the Mediterranean coast, came as four Arab foreign ministers arrived for an unprecedented summit that shows Israel’s growing role in the Middle East
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Police officers collecting evidence at the scene of an attack in Hadera, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Recalibrates Its Attack
item.description: Plus a historic summit in Israel and economic turmoil in Sri Lanka.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with anti-tank weapons near the front lines north of Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Zelensky, Roots in Show Business, Presses for an Oscar Appearance
item.description: The Ukrainian president was looking for support from Hollywood. But his appeal to speak during the Oscars encountered drama of its own.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky on set during the filming of his television show “Servant of the People” in February 2019.

item.title: American Officials Try to Walk Back Biden’s Comments on Putin
item.description: Senior officials, including Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, and top lawmakers stressed that the United States was not seeking regime change in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Chris Cameron and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Biden’s remark in a speech in Warsaw that President Vladimir V. Putin “cannot remain in power” was not meant as a call for regime change, U.S. officials said Sunday.

item.title: Éric Zemmour Vows to Fight for Identity and Prosperity
item.description: Éric Zemmour, a far-right pundit, tried to revive his flagging campaign Sunday in a place that is familiar to hopefuls of his ilk.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Éric Zemmour drew a large crowd at a rally on Sunday in Paris, but his campaign for the French presidency has stumbled in recent weeks.

item.title: Putin Says Tchaikovsky Is Being Canceled. The Met Opera Disagrees.
item.description: The company’s revival of “Eugene Onegin” gives the lie to the Russian president’s claim that his country’s composers are suffering in the West.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe

item.title: Blinken to Press Mideast Allies for Stronger Support for Ukraine
item.description: The countries, which have their own relationships with Russia, have provided some modest backing, but Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will ask for more.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Capitol Hill last year. While in the Middle East this week, he will be discussing “various means of support that Israel and other countries can give to Ukraine.”
